Title.evidence: Infrapatellar Fat Pad Excision in Minimally Invasive Total Knee Arthroplasty: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised into two groups: 45 patients with complete infrapatellar fat pad excision and 45 without.

Participants.evidence: This randomised controlled trial was conducted at a single institution, involving 90 patients undergoing MIS TKA.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised into two groups: 45 patients with complete infrapatellar fat pad excision and 45 without.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was anterior knee pain, assessed at 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, and 1 year postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved using a computer-generated sequence with allocation concealment.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Participants were randomised into two groups: 45 patients with complete infrapatellar fat pad excision and 45 without.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Complete follow-up data were available for 77 of 90 patients (86%). The analysis was conducted on an intention-to-treat basis.

Result_Outcome.evidence: However, the excision group experienced more anterior knee pain (8.3% versus 0%; p = 0.03; 95% CI, âˆ’0.007 to 0.174).

Harms.evidence: No patellar complications were observed in either group.
